Shape: Bulky gull-like seabird; the largest and most barrel chested of the three jaegers. At all ages, note broad wings. Breeding adults are unique with elongated spoon-shaped central tail feathers. Bill is also thicker than other jaegers.
Compared Size: Larger than a Parasitic Jaeger; smaller than a Herring Gull.

description: Note blackish-brown upperparts, messy black cap that extends below the bill, and extensive white flash on upper and underside of outer wing. Rare dark morph adult is entirely blackish-brown but still has white wing flashes. Immature birds are variable, but in general they are barred with brown above and have bold black-and-white bars on the underwing and undertail coverts. Typically shows white shafts on 6 to 8 outer wing feathers (more than other jaegers) and more obvious white flash on underwing.
All jaegers chase other birds and steal their food. Pomarine Jaegers have a powerful, direct flight style and are less acrobatic than the smaller jaegers.
Breeds on Arctic tundra, spends the rest of the year at sea.
